newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan's Formosa to seek coal in Australia - paper.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan's Formosa to seek coal in Australia - paper.

text.p: Formosa Plastics, one of Taiwan's biggest conglomerates, will send chairman Wang Yung-ching to Australia with an eye to importing coal, a major Taipei newspaper reported on Tuesday.

"Wang Yung-ching will personally lead a high-level team to inspect coal resources in Australia around the Mid-Autumn Festival," the Commercial Times newspaper reported, quoting unnamed sources. The festival falls on September 27.
Wang would visit the northeastern state of Queensland to seek coal imports for Formosa's planned petrochemical complex in southern Taiwan, the sources said.
Formosa obtained government approval in 1992 to build the multibillion-dollar complex, including a naphtha cracker, but construction has been delayed by environmental protests.
Formosa plans to build a power plant near the complex.
Taiwan's government promised to assist the Formosa complex after the group, under government pressure, withdrew an application to build a US$3 billion power station in China.
The Formosa team would be the first Taiwan business delegation to visit Australia after the two sides held a high-profile business forum in Taipei in early September.
Taiwan and Australia vowed at the forum to strengthen economic and trade ties.
Coal demand from the Formosa complex would total 15 million tonnes a year in 2000, the newspaper said.
Formosa officials declined to comment on the report.
State-run Taiwan Power Company, the island's main coal importer, imported 13.8 million tonnes of coal in 1995, of which South Africa and Australia each accounted for about 30 percent.
Some 20 percent of the coal was imported from Indonesia and the rest was from the United States and elsewhere.

Business contacts have grown in 1996 since Taiwan's An Feng group and Australia's Kingstream Resources agreed to build a US$1.2 billion slab mill in Australia with an annual production of 2.4 million tonnes of slab.
In August, Australia's conservative government said it was considering selling uranium to Taiwan, which said it welcomed the move under international safety standards.
